title: Student left fighting for life hours after telling boyfriend she had a headache
text:

Hours after a student told her boyfriend she had a headache she was fighting to survive and facing life in a permanent vegetative state.

Sophia Dempsey, from Warrington , told her boyfriend Joe she was going to skip university as she felt ill.

Just a few short hours later the 21-year-old fell unconscious as her home in Leicester and was rushed to hospital, The Liverpool Echo reported.

Doctors told her friends and family Sophia, who had had a stroke, might not survive the night.

The then 18-year-old did make it through to the next day, eventually waking up a fortnight later.

While she was battling her way back to consciousness medics told Joe that she might spend the rest of her life in a vegetative state.

The video game art and design student fought back against the illness.

Despite the fact her movement and speech is still badly affected ten years on, she is determined to be independent.

(Image: LiverpoolEcho/ WS)

“I still can’t believe I suffered a stroke at 18," she said.

"On the day I fell unconscious, I had a terrible headache and told Joe I was going to stay at home rather than go into university.

"Joe texted me during the morning to see how I was – and came home after I didn’t reply.”

Strokes occur when the blood supply to parts of the brain is cut off, either by a blood clot – which Sophia had suffered, deep inside her brain – or a burst blood vessel.

Sophia, who is now and married to Joe, added: “It took me just under two weeks to come round, and a lot longer to be able to start thinking about what had happened to me.

"The first thing I did was look for answers.

"There were lots of possible causes suggested – diet, stress and high blood pressure were among the things mentioned, but I might never know.

"I just think I was terribly unlucky.”

At the time of her stroke Sophia and Joe had been dating for two years.

(Image: LiverpoolEcho/ WS)

Twelve years later they are still together, Joe having been there every step of the way and now working full time as her carer.

He said: “Sophia’s been brilliant.

"She accepted what happened to her and has been determined to get the right treatment and get as well as she possibly can.

"Like Sophia, I just can’t believe it was a stroke.

"When it happened, it was as if she had been born again.

"She couldn’t do anything for herself at first – and I was so overjoyed when she was able to just squeeze my finger. That was massive.”

Since suffering the stroke Sophia, who still struggles with muscle spasticity, has been on a long road to recover.

Dr Ganesh Bavikatte, a neurorehabilitation specialist who has treated Sophia, said: “I can’t really put into words the importance of post-stroke rehabilitation.

"Unfortunately, many stroke survivors do not get referred to a spasticity specialist early enough and so do not get the treatment they need leading to a diminished quality of life.”

Sophia followed a rehabilitation plan which helped her regain use of her left arm and speech.

She was well enough to ride along with Joe to Italy in a specially-adapted motorcyle.

(Image: LiverpoolEcho/ WS)

Sophia said: “It’s been a case of gradual improvements.

"The main problems have been with my speech, and movement on my left side.

"I have got better – thanks to speech therapy and occupational therapy and exercise – but everything takes a great deal of effort and concentration.

"I use a walking stick but can only manage short distances, so I have a chair, and it doesn’t take me long before I get tired.

"But I’m determined to live as full a life as possible.”
description: Sophia Dempsey, from Warrington, skipped university as she felt ill - but her condition soon worsened
